subject: Re: [junit] Newbie best practice question
msgSnippet: ... bettingSession should be a new instance in setUp, so it doesn t really matter. If it s not a new instance for every test, you can use tearDown to make sure
messageBody:
On Wednesday 14 July 2004 03:34 pm, Chip Dunning wrote:
> The class that I wish to test keeps a private ArrayList. I expose the
> following...
>
> public ArrayList getList();
> public void setList(ArrayList);
> public void clearList();
> public void inList(String);
>
>
> I am ignoring the get and sets, because they are simple - but I want to
> test the clearList() and inList() code. The clear I am testing because it
> has some secondary effects instead of just calling the clear() function.
> The inList is shown below.
>
>
> public void testInTransactionSet() {
>   bettingSession.clearTransactions();
>
>   ArrayList wagerList = new ArrayList();
>   for (int x = 0; x < 20; x++) {
>     WagerInfo wager = new WagerInfo();
>     wager.setTicketID("" + x);
>     WagerTransactionSet wagerSet = new WagerTransactionSet(wager);
>     wagerList.add(wagerSet);
>   }
>   bettingSession.setTransaction(wagerList);
>
>   boolean actualReturn = bettingSession.inTransactionSet("5");
>   assertEquals("return value", true, actualReturn);
>    
>   actualReturn = bettingSession.inTransactionSet("1234");
>   assertEquals("return value", false, actualReturn);
>
>   actualReturn = bettingSession.inTransactionSet("BadXact");
>   assertEquals("return value", false, actualReturn);}
>
>
> From a best practices viewpoint - do people clear any changes they make
> before they exit their test? I currently don't call the clear just before
> exit, but I was wondering if I should so that other tests are not affected
> by any artifacts that I leave laying around.

bettingSession should be a new instance in setUp, so it doesn't really matter.
If it's not a new instance for every test, you can use tearDown to make sure
it's back to a 'sane' state.
